ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Focused ion beam fabrication and magneto-electrical transport properties of La0.67Ca0.33MnO3 nanobridge

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Center for Optoelectronics Materials and Devices
State Key Laboratory of Information Photonics and Optical Communication, School of Science
Affiliation.OrgName: Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications
The State University of New York at Potsdam

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: La0.67Ca0.33MnO3 particle films with an average particle size of ~150 nm were grown on single-crystal silicon substrate using pulsed electron deposition technique and then focused ion beam was introduced to fabricate nanobridge in size of 300 × 900 nm on the particle film. The magneto-transport properties of both samples were studied. For the film, there is only one resistance peak at 182 K in temperature-dependent resistance (R–T) curves, which is far lower than ferromagnetic–paramagnetic transition temperature (T C) of 250 K. When compared to the film, double peaks were observed in both R–T curves and magnetoresistance dependent on temperature (MR–T) curves of the nanobridge, one peak is at 186 K, which is very close to metal–insulator transition temperature (T P) of film, the other one is at 250 K, which is close to the T C of film, and these two peaks caused separately by grain and grain boundary (GB), which demonstrated that the electrical transport behavior of grain was separated from that of GB.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Colossal magnetoresistance (CMR) materials have attracted considerable attention because of its excellent magnetic and electrical properties [1–7]. In the past decade many efforts have been devoted to enhance the magnetoresistance (MR), especially low field MR, due to the potential technological applications [8–10]. Large MR was found in polycrystalline films, ceramic samples and artificially grain boundary junction [11–17], these results led to the extensive studies on the GB effects on the magneto-transport properties of CMR materials. The electron transport through the GB is substantially different from that through the grain. There are two different explanations of GB contributing to MR, one is spin-dependent tunneling through insulating layer between two grains, and the other is spin-dependent scattering in the GB [11, 18, 19]. Since the sample includes two parts: GB and grain, the behavior caused by these two parts should be observed in same experimental results. For example, the peak of resistance caused by grain should be same to that of single crystal, at T C, and the peak of resistance caused by GB is near to metal–insulator transition temperature (T P), but in fact, nearly all experimental results observed only one peak caused by GB, because the GB with high resistance dominates the transport properties, the behavior of grain was overwhelmed. So separating the behavior of grain from GB is essential to get further evidence from more direct experiments and offer opportunities to study the interplay of grain and GB. One way to do that is shrinkage the sample size, with the decrease of size, the percentage of resistance caused by GB will decrease, when the resistances of GB and grain are comparable, the behavior of grain is anticipated to be observed. With the development of micro/nanofabrication technology, to fabricate structure with very small size, e.g., micro/nano-size, is possible and offers opportunity to study the physical properties in such scale.

In this paper, focused ion beam (FIB) was used to fabricate La0.67Ca0.33MnO3 (LCMO) bridge in nanoscale on LCMO particles film deposited by pulsed electron deposition (PED) technique. FIB is one of most widely used technique in the semiconductor industry for failure analysis, device modifications, and micro–nanocomponent fabrication, it is highly suitable for microfabrication due to its small spot size and stable operating conditions [20]. The morphology, magnetic properties and magneto-transport properties were measured. As expected, we observed two peaks in both temperature-dependent resistance curves and temperature-dependent magnetoresistance curves of nanobridge, which means that the behavior of grain was separated from the behavior of GB.

Section1.Heading: Experiments
Section1.Para:
LCMO thin film was deposited on single-crystal silicon substrate using PED technology from a stoichiometric polycrystalline LCMO target. The substrate temperature was 973 K, and the deposition atmosphere is under pure oxygen with a pressure of 10 mTorr. After deposition, a in situ post-annealing was performed to relieve the strain and eliminate the oxygen vacancy in film [21–23], the chamber was filled by oxygen gas up to 760 mTorr, the heater was maintained at 973 K for 30 min, then the power was switched off, and the samples were cooled down to room temperature naturally. In the PED process, a pulsed high power and high energy density electron beam penetrates about 1 µm into the target, as a result, thermodynamic properties of the target materials become unimportant in the evaporation process. In the case of complex, multi-component materials, this is particularly advantageous. It is easy to deposit particle film because of the nature of PED, the particle film with the thickness of about 200 nm in the average grain size ~150 nm. To reduce the electrical transport area, focused ion beam (FIB from FEI company) was used to pattern nanobridge in LCMO particle film, this system employs a Ga-liquid metal ion source and the highest accelerating voltage is 30 keV. The fabrication process is schematically drawn in Fig. 1. The temperature-dependent magnetizations with zero field cooling (ZFC) and field cooling (FC) were measured on quantum design magnetic properties measurement system (MPMS). Electronic transport properties of LCMO thin film and nanobridge were measured using physical properties measurement system (PPMS from Quantum Design Company) with standard four-probe method. Silver paint was used for the electrical contacts.
Fig. 1
Schematic drawing of fabrication process of LCMO nanobridge, a substrate, b LCMO film deposition, c nanobridge fabrication by FIB and d four-electrode test configure

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
The morphologies of LCMO particle film and fabricated nanobridge are shown in Fig. 2a, from the results of surface profiler, the average grain size is about 150 nm. Figure 2b is the SEM picture of nanobridge, it can be seen that there are only a few grains and not so much GB in the bridge, the size of the bridge is about 300 × 900 nm. There are several reports on the inherent side effects from the FIB milling process due to the Ga+ ion implantation and focused ion bombardment [24, 25], such side effects will reduce the effective size of the fabricated bridge. In our case, taking into account the lateral implantation depth of 10–20 nm [26], the effective size of the fabricated bridge is of more than 250 nm.
Fig. 2
a SEM image of deposited LCMO film, b SEM image of fabricated LCMO nanobridge

The results of ZFC and FC are shown in Fig. 3. The ZFC magnetization was measured in the warming process with a magnetic field of 100 Oe applied after cooling the sample down to 5 K without magnetic field, and the FC magnetization was measured in the warming process with a magnetic field of 100 Oe applied after cooling the sample down to 5 K under 1 T magnetic field. From the figure, it can be seen that the T C of particle film is 250 K, and ZFC and FC curves are split below T C, which is normal in bulk sample or film with quantity of GB.
Fig. 3
Magnetization with zero field cooling (ZFC) and field cooling (FC) for the particle LCMO film

The temperature dependence of resistance has been measured down to 5 K. Figure 4a is the R–T curves of film under different magnetic fields, without magnetic field T P is 181 K, peak resistance is 70.74 kΩ, and the T P is much lower than the single-crystal film, such shifting caused by GB. The T P shifts to high temperature upon applying magnetic field. The resistance shows a large upturn below 20 K, the upturn is maybe because of weak localization resulting from the disorder introduced by the nano-size effect, which has been observed in manganites thin film with GBs. Such behavior was explained based on several theories including weak localization. A characteristic signature of weak localization is the strong temperature-dependent negative magnetoresistance at low temperature [27–31]. Figure 4b shows MR–T curves of LCMO film under different magnetic fields. The MR is defined as MR = [(R 0 − R H)/R 0] × 100 %, where R 0 and R H are the resistances without and with magnetic field. The MR peaks at 174 K without magnetic field, which is nearly same to T P. The peak of MR also shifts to high temperature direction with the increase of magnetic field. The MR is not sensitive to temperature below T P. A linear relationship between the applied voltage and the resulting electric current confirms that the film has no tunneling effect, the curves are shown in Fig. 4c.
Fig. 4
a Resistance of LCMO film as a function of temperature under magnetic fields of H = 0, 1, 4, 7 T, b temperature dependence of magnetoresistance under magnetic fields of H = 1, 4, 7 T, c a typical voltage versus current curves of LCMO film at temperature of 5 and 300 K

Figure 5a shows R–T curves of LCMO nanobridge with different magnetic field. From the figure, we can see that the curves are different from that of LCMO film, two peaks were clearly observed. Without magnetic field, one peak with peak resistance 12.7 MΩ is at 186 K, which is very close to T P of bare film, the peak resistance is much larger than that of film. The other peak with peak resistance 4.7 MΩ is at 250 K, which is near to the T C of film. Figure 5b illustrates the MR–T curves and the curves show two peaks either, a sharp transition at 234 K followed by a broad transition at 180 K. These two peaks observed in R–T curves and MR–T curves were considered to be caused by GB and grain separately, low temperature peak caused by GB and high temperature peak caused by grain.
Fig. 5
a Temperature dependence of resistance of nanobridge under magnetic fields of H = 1, 4, 7 T, inset shows the morphology of bridge, b temperature dependence of magnetoresistance of nanobridge under magnetic fields of H = 1, 4, 7 T, c a typical voltage versus current curves of LCMO nanobridge at temperature of 50 and 300 K

Core–shell model was normally used to explain the magneto-transport behavior in the particle film, [32, 33] each particle contains core and shell, the core is the inner part of grain, and the shell is the surface of grain, also named grain boundary (GB). The GB is more chaotic than the grain, and therefore, GB dominates the magneto-transport properties, so it is difficult to observe the effect of magnetic phase change of grain on the transport properties. For the nanobridge, as is shown in Fig. 2, there are only several grains and a little GB in the LCMO bridge, the quantity of grains and GB was largely reduced, but the ratio of grain and GB should be kept unchanged, so the emerge of peak at ~250 K cannot attribute to the reduction of grain and GB. The possible reason to explain the phenomenon is that the movement of electron was strictly limited to the small area, and directionally, in the nanobridge, the resistance caused by grain and the resistance caused by GB are in series, and the resistance caused by paramagnetic–ferromagnetic transition can be obviously observed in R–T curves. The separation of transport behaviors of grain and GB offers an opportunity to further study the physical mechanism of interplay between grain and GB in CMR materials. The V–I curves for nanobridge were measured at temperatures of 50 and 300 K, as is shown in Fig. 5c, the linearity of the V–I curves indicates no electronic tunneling process in the structure.

In our previous work, microbridges fabricated on epitaxial LCMO were very sensitive to the shrinkage of width [34], the metal–insulator transition and magnetoresistance behavior disappeared when the width of bridge decreased to 500 nm, meaning the instability in nano-magnetoeletronic device. The nanobridge fabricated on LCMO particle films shows both metal–insulator transition and magnetoresistance behavior in width of 300 nm, demonstrating the practical applications in nano-magnetic device.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In summary, PED technique was used to deposit LCMO particle films and then 300 × 900 nm LCMO nanobridge was fabricated using FIB technology in the particle film. Magneto-electrical transport properties of both the film and the nanobridge were studied. For the film, the behavior of grain was overwhelmed by the GB. For the nanobridge, the behaviors of grain as well as GB were observed in both R–T curves and MR–T curves, which mean the behavior of grain was separated from that of GB in nanobridge.
